title: Welcome
text:
I am a graduate student in Biomedical Engineering at Case Western Reserve University, with dual bachelor‚Äôs degrees in Biomedical Engineering and Computer Science. Currently, I am conducting research at the Cardiovascular Innovation Research Center (CIRC) at Cleveland Clinic Foundation, where I collaborate with Siemens technical specialists on advanced cardiac MRI data processing and analysis.
My research focuses on developing next-generation cardiac diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) techniques and integrating machine learning approaches into cardiovascular imaging applications. I am passionate about leveraging computational methods to solve complex biomedical challenges, particularly in medical imaging and cardiac health.
With strong expertise in Python and Java programming, I combine my engineering background with clinical applications to advance the field of cardiac imaging. I am dedicated to translating novel technologies into practical clinical solutions that can improve patient care.

title: Research Experience
text:
Cardiovascular Innovation Research Center, Cleveland Clinic Foundation
August 2024 ‚Äì Present
Advisor: Dr.¬†Christopher Nguyen



I am working at the intersection of cardiology, biomedical engineering, and radiology to develop advanced cardiac MRI data processing techniques. This research is part of CIRC‚Äôs mission to rapidly translate novel technologies into clinical applications.




Industry Collaboration: Working directly with Siemens technical specialists to develop and optimize cardiac MRI data processing pipelines for diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) analysis
Algorithm Development: Implementing advanced image reconstruction algorithms to improve the quality and accuracy of diffusion-weighted cardiac MRI sequences
Clinical Application: Processing and analyzing cardiac DTI datasets to evaluate myocardial fiber architecture and assess cardiac microstructure changes in various pathological conditions
Automation Tools: Developing Python-based tools for automated helix angle calculation and transmural fiber orientation mapping in cardiac tissue
Machine Learning Integration: Implementing deep learning techniques to enhance cardiac segmentation and automate ROI selection in DTI analysis workflows
Clinical Validation: Working with clinical datasets to validate novel DTI metrics for assessment of myocardial remodeling and fibrosis





Software: INDI cardiac imaging platform, 3D Slicer, MATLAB
Programming: Python (primary), MATLAB for signal processing
Libraries: TensorFlow, OpenCV, NumPy, SciPy
Data Format: DICOM, NIfTI

title: Research Experience
text:
Previous Research

Automatic Skull Stripping for Mouse Brain MRI
Department of Biomedical Engineering, Case Western Reserve University
January 2024 ‚Äì May 2025
Advisor: Dr.¬†Xin Yu


Project Overview
Developed a deep learning-based solution for automated skull stripping in preclinical neuroimaging studies, addressing a critical bottleneck in mouse brain MRI analysis pipelines.


Key Achievements

High Accuracy: Achieved 95% accuracy in validation datasets using a custom U-Net architecture
Performance Optimization: Reduced processing time by 70% compared to traditional methods
Robust Pipeline: Created a comprehensive preprocessing pipeline to standardize MRI data from different acquisition protocols and scanner types
Clinical Validation: Validated against manual segmentation by expert annotators, demonstrating superior consistency and reproducibility
User Interface: Developed a user-friendly Python interface for batch processing of large neuroimaging datasets



Technical Implementation
# Example workflow
- Data preprocessing and standardization
- 3D U-Net model for segmentation
- Post-processing refinement
- Automated quality assessment
- Batch processing capabilities


Impact
This tool is now being used by multiple research groups for high-throughput analysis of mouse brain MRI data, significantly accelerating preclinical neuroimaging studies.

title: Teaching Experience
text:
Teaching Appointments

Lead Teaching Assistant

MATH 302: Discrete Mathematics
Case Western Reserve University | Summer 2024

Responsibilities: - Provided comprehensive support for advanced mathematical concepts including graph theory, combinatorics, and algorithm analysis - Conducted weekly office hours offering individualized problem-solving guidance - Developed supplementary materials and practice problems to enhance student understanding - Graded all assignments, quizzes, and exams with detailed feedback
Impact: - Helped improve class average by 15% through targeted review sessions - Received positive feedback from students for clear explanations of complex topics - Created a comprehensive study guide that was adopted for future semesters





Teaching Assistant

ENGR 210: Introduction to Circuits and Instrumentation
Case Western Reserve University | Spring 2023 ‚Äì Spring 2025

Responsibilities: - Facilitated hands-on laboratory sessions for 60+ students across multiple sections - Demonstrated experimental setups including oscilloscopes, function generators, and multimeters - Ensured adherence to safety protocols in electrical engineering labs - Provided real-time troubleshooting support during experiments
Key Contributions: - Developed visual aids and quick reference guides for common circuit configurations - Implemented a peer-mentoring system that improved lab completion rates - Created video tutorials for remote learners during hybrid instruction periods
Topics Covered: - Basic circuit analysis (Ohm‚Äôs Law, Kirchhoff‚Äôs Laws) - AC/DC circuit behavior - Operational amplifiers - Digital logic circuits - Instrumentation and measurement techniques





Teaching Assistant

EBME 360: Biomedical Instrumentation Laboratory
Case Western Reserve University | Spring 2024

Responsibilities: - Guided students through advanced biomedical instrumentation techniques - Supervised experiments involving physiological signal acquisition and processing - Taught proper use of specialized equipment (ECG, EMG, pulse oximeters) - Evaluated laboratory reports and provided constructive feedback
Laboratory Modules: - Biopotential measurements (ECG, EMG, EEG) - Biomedical transducers and sensors - Signal conditioning and filtering - Digital signal processing for biomedical applications - Medical device safety and standards
Achievements: - Redesigned lab protocols to improve clarity and reduce completion time - Mentored student teams on final instrumentation design projects - Contributed to curriculum updates based on student feedback
